title: Quiz 3: Central Dogma of Molecular Biology
description: Assess your understanding of the molecular structure of DNA, RNA and proteins.

items.question: This consists of two long polynucleotide chains composed of four types of nucleotide subunits.
choices: RNA molecule
DNA molecule
Polysaccharide
Central Dogma
items.explanation: Deoxyribonucleic acid is a polymer composed of two polynucleotide chains that coil around each other to form a double helix carrying genetic instructions for the development, functioning, growth and reproduction of all known organisms and many viruses. DNA and ribonucleic acid are nucleic acids.

items.question: Which of the following are the nitrogen bases of a DNA molecule?
choices: Adenine, Thymine, Guanine and Cytosine
Adenine, Uracil, Guanine and Cytosine
Adenine, Uracil, Thymine and Cytosine
Adenine, Uracil, Guanine and Thymine
items.explanation: There are four nucleotides, or bases, in DNA: adenine (A), cytosine (C), guanine (G), and thymine (T). These bases form specific pairs (A with T, and G with C).

items.question: Why does Messenger RNA (mRNA) plays as a transcript copy of a gene?
choices: mRNA does not provide codes to a specific polypeptide.
mRNA provides arrangement to a specific polypeptide.
mRNA provides codes to a specific polypeptide.
mRNA does not provide codes to a specific polypeptide.
items.explanation: Messenger RNA (mRNA) is a single-stranded RNA molecule that is complementary to one of the DNA strands of a gene which provides codes to a specific polypeptide.

items.question: Why does the messenger RNA (mRNA) molecule leaves the cell nucleus and enters the cytoplasm?
choices: It leaves the cell nucleus and enters the cytoplasm, where it prepares the breaking down of the protein, which it encodes.
It leaves the cell nucleus and enters the cytoplasm, where it directs the synthesis of the protein, which it encodes.
It leaves the cell nucleus and enters the cytoplasm, where it degrades the protein, which it encodes.
It leaves the cell nucleus and enters the cytoplasm, where it polymerizes the protein, which it encodes.
items.explanation: Transcription is the process of making an RNA copy of a gene sequence. This copy, called a messenger RNA (mRNA) molecule, leaves the cell nucleus and enters the cytoplasm, where it directs the synthesis of the protein, which it encodes.

items.question: What do you think will happen to proteins as the end products of the decoding process that starts with the information in cellular DNA?
choices: they will not serve as the catalysts for virtually every biochemical reaction that occurs in living things.
they will serve as the catalysts for virtually every biochemical reaction that occurs in living things.
they will prepare the catalysts for virtually every biochemical reaction that occurs in living things.
they will not prepare the catalysts for virtually every biochemical reaction that occurs in living things.
items.explanation: Proteins are the end products of the decoding process that starts with the information in cellular DNA. As workhorses of the cell, proteins compose structural and motor elements in the cell, and they serve as the catalysts for virtually every biochemical reaction that occurs in living things.

items.question: Which of the following is considered as the building blocks of proteins?
choices: amino acids
nucleotides
nitrogen bases
carboxyl group
items.explanation: Amino acids are molecules that combine to form proteins. Amino acids and proteins are the building blocks of life. When proteins are digested or broken down, amino acids are left.

items.question: Which of the following links together the amino acids?
choices: Peptide Bonds
Polysaccharide Bonds
Carboxyl Bonds
Hydrogen Bonds
items.explanation: A peptide bond is basically an amide-type of covalent chemical bond. This bond links two consecutive alpha-amino acids from C1 (carbon number one) of one alpha-amino acid and N2 (nitrogen number two) of another. This linkage is found along a peptide or protein chain.

items.question: Why does the process on how the DNA makes proteins is called the “Central Dogma”?
choices: because Central Dogma's goal is to use instructions in the DNA to convert it into a tRNA
because Central Dogma's goal is to use instructions in the DNA to convert it into a not a functional product
because Central Dogma's goal is to use instructions in the DNA to convert it into a functional product
because Central Dogma's goal is to use instructions in the DNA to convert it into a rRNA
items.explanation: The 'Central Dogma' is the process by which the instructions in DNA are converted into a functional product.

items.question: Some events that take place during the synthesis of a specific protein are listed below. A.) Messenger RNA attaches to a ribosome. B.) DNA serves as a template for RNA production. C.) TransferRNA bonds to a specific codon. D.) Amino acids are bonded together. E.) RNA moves from the nucleus to the cytoplasm.
choices: BEACD
DAECB
BCEDA
CBAED
items.explanation: Protein synthesis actually consists of two processes — transcription and translation. In eukaryotic cells, transcription takes place in the nucleus. During transcription, DNA is used as a template to make a molecule of messenger RNA (mRNA). The molecule of mRNA then leaves the nucleus and goes to a ribosome in the cytoplasm, where translation occurs. During translation, the genetic code in mRNA is read and used to make a protein. These two processes are summed up by the central dogma of molecular biology: DNA → RNA → Protein.

items.question: What do you think will happen if in alternative splicing, individual exons are neither spliced nor included?
choices: it will give rise to several different possible mRNA products
it will not give rise to several different possible mRNA products
it will not give rise to several different possible transcriptions
it will not give rise to several different possible translations
items.explanation: In alternative splicing, individual exons are either spliced or included, giving rise to several different possible mRNA products. Each mRNA product codes for a different protein isoform; these protein isoforms differ in their peptide sequence and therefore their biological activity. It is estimated that up to 60% of human gene products undergo alternative splicing.
